item.title: Hello world!
item.dc:creator: tsarouchi
item.content:encoded: Ladies & Gentlemen! Τσαρούχι Soundsystems' official blog/mini-site is a fact. Hosted by wordpress, "tsarouchi" is our new internet-base. Currently under construction, offers an About section (facts, profile and backround of Τσαρούχι Soundsystem and our crew), a Contact section (links and info in order to keep up with Τσ) , Sets & Mixes section (every single DJ Set, Mix, MiniMix or Mixtape online, gathered in one place) and of course, The Blog (news and announcements). Enjoy! Τσαρούχι Soundsystem: "Electrifying Your Mind"

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: tsarouchi
item.content:encoded: Τσαρούχι Soundsystem is a cultural collective based in Crete. Forged in the '90s, Τσαρούχι (both crew and supporters), against todays' trends, aim at providing an artistic liberation to the un-pop-ular. On the music side, even though in the beginning Τσαρούχι had a rock orientation (alternative/indie mostly) with some big-beat touches, nowadays electro is our oyster. From smooth TripHop, Dub and Tech House to rough Jungle, Techno and Breakbeat, maintaining the utmost respect to our influences (Rock, HipHop, Blues, Shoegaze & BritPop ). In this webspace you can find more about who we are, listen to what we do, browse some (demo) tunes, communicate with the crew, and of course, browse the blog. "ELECTRIFYING YOUR MIND"

item.title: Featured Video #1 [Winstons - Amen Brother]
item.dc:creator: tsarouchi
item.content:encoded:
Electro History-X: The Amen Break The "Amen Break" was a brief drum solo performed in 1969 by Gregory Cylvester "G. C." Coleman in the song "Amen, Brother" performed by the 1960s funk and soul outfit The Winstons. It gained fame from the 1980s onwards when four bars (5.2 seconds) sampled from the drum-solo (or imitations thereof) became very widely used as sampled drum loops in hip hop, jungle and drum and bass music.

Some Tracks based on the Amen Break:

  • Dj Zinc - Super Sharp Shooter
  • N.W.A. - Straight Outta Compton
  • Snow - Informer
  • UK Apache & Shy FX - Original Nuttah
  • Asian Dub Foundation - Flyover
  • Prodigy - Mindfields
  • Omni Trio - Renegade Snares
Also appears at tracks by: Dillinja, Freestylers, Beastie Boys, Lemon D, DJ Shadow, DJ SS, Aphex Twin, Rebel MC, Amon Tobin and many many others... Listen to it (1:27-1:33) [youtube=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GxZuq57_bYM]

item.title: Dance Anthemns of the 90s [part 1: the pops]
item.dc:creator: tsarouchi
item.content:encoded:
Electro History X: Electro in the 1990s [part 1: Influential dance tunes that reached the mainstream ]
  • Underworld - Born Slippy (NUXX) [1995-1996]
    • Originally realeased in January 1995 as a B-Side to "Born Slippy", received little attention.  "Born Slippy .NUXX" was re-released as a single in 1996 charting #2 in UK and becoming the manifest of modern dance music, up to this day. It was voted #1 dance tune in Mixmag’s 25th Anniversary Awards. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XiMrrleH_hI&NR trivia: Born Slippy was the name of a greyhound the band bet on and won, and the .NUXX version took it's name from a computer error that added that suffix to the name of their working file
  • Hybrid - Finished Symphony [1999]
    • Released as a single in 1999 and featured on their debut album entitled "Wide Angle", was a remake of "Symphony", an older -unreleased- track by Hybrid. It became quite popular, but it's artistic impact was bigger than it's commercial success. It was the first breakbeat song that combined elements of trance, progressive house and symphonic music. A maxi-single with remixes, entitled "Finished Symphony Remixed" was released in 2008" http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yoV9d9y-DdQ trivia: The orchestral parts were performed by The Russian Federal Orchestra.
  • Puretone - Addicted to Bass [1998]
    • When someone uses the words "Australia" and "D&B" most people think of Pendulum. And that's too bad... "Addicted to Bass" is the very first Drum and Bass tune that charted #2 in the UK. Written by the Australian band Puretone, it was meant to be the tune that made the term Drum and Bass slip into the mainstream. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wmwGGLrDvfE trivia: In Australia reached just #19 in the charts.
  • Chemical Brothers - Block Rockin' Beats [1997]
    • "Block Rockin' Beats" received a Grammy award for "Best Instrumental Rock Perfomance" and that's exactly why this song is on this list. Chemical Brothers considered to be the pioneers of the Big Beat genre for some reason... When Tom Rowlands and Ed Simons wrote this song we cannot know if they wanted to make an electronic rock tune or a rock-ish electro tune. Embracing both rock and electro fans, reached a wide audience and instantly became #1 in the UK. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fSp81g9kzu8 trivia: Chemical Brothers original called themselves Dust Brothers (after a hip hop duo with that name) and changed it when the original Dust Brothers threatened legal action over the use of their name.
  • FatBoy Slim - Right Here, Right Now [1999]
    • Take an artist with one of the best backgrounds in music industry. At the peak of his career, he made an album that was about to become his evangelion. Choose a catchy song from it. Add a cool video to this tune, and you've got "Right Here, Right Now". http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ub747pprmJ8 trivia: The lyrics "right here, right now" are a sample of Angela Bassett's voice from the film Strange Days
  • Future Sound Of London - Papua New Guinea [1991]
    • The debut single from the FSOL (and later appeared on the album "Accelerator") is probably the most remixed song of it's era, having various remixes released up to this day (my personal pick is Hybrids' version). The original version is a breakbeat track, featuring numerous samples from "Radio Babylon" of Meat Beat Manifesto and one of the most recognized piano melodies in electronic music. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OjQqYFNK50M trivia: Papua New Guinea 2001 is a remixes collection released in 2002 featuring versions by Satoshie Tomiie, Hybrid, Blue States and Simian Mobile Disco
  • Baby D - Let Me Be Your Fantasy [1992]
    • Featuring female vocals in a breakbeat track -even nowadays- is kinda risky. Perhaps that's the reason why Baby Ds' "Let Me Be Your Fantasy" first release in 1992, draw the attention of very few DJs. However, after it's re-issue in 1994, entered the charts in position #3 and peaked #1. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7Wt1nvsoKno trivia: Baby D released his version of Kongis' "Everybody's Got To Learn Sometime", entitled I Need Your Loving" (UK #3)

item.title: Featured Video #2 [James Brown - Funky Drummer]
item.dc:creator: tsarouchi
item.content:encoded:
Electro History-X: Funky Drummer "Funky Drummer" was recorded on November 1969, and originally released as a two-part single in March 1970. It did not receive an  album release until the compilation "In the Jungle Groove" (1986). By then, it was already one of the most sampled tracks. The drum break comes late in the recording, with a request to "give the drummer some", by James Brown. From the mid 80s, up to today the Funky Drummer Loop was an essential element in numerous electronic music track (Hip Hop and Breakbeat mostly).  The Funky Drummer Break among with The Amen Break are definitely the most sampled drum loops ever.

Some Tracks based on the Funky Drummer Break:

  • Isaac Hayes - Ikes' Mood (convoitise Re-Break)
  • Public Enemy - Rebel Without A Pause
  • Coldcut - Say Kids What Time Is It
  • Run DMC - Runs' House
  • N.W.A. - Quiet On Tha Set
  • Baby D - Let Me Be Your Fantasy
  • Pizzicato Five - This Can't Be Love
Also appears at tracks by: Ice Cube, Beastie Boys, DJ Shadow, De La Soul, Dr.Dre, Ultramagnetic MCs',  K-OS, Mos Def, and others... Listen to it (5:35-5:55) [youtube=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dNP8tbDMZNE]

item.title: I Am The Elephant, U Are The Mouse
item.dc:creator: tsarouchi
item.content:encoded:
I Am The Elephant, U Are The Mouse: The Movie, The Soundtrack, The Theft "I Am The Elephant, U Are The Mouse" is a movie, released quite a long time ago. I bet that, you've never seen it, never heard of it and I can assume that it's probably a lousy movie. This particular movie had a OST composed and recorded in 1994. There is a microscopic chance that you might have listened to it, a bit more possible is that you might have heard of it, but it's a fact that it's a masterpiece of '90s indie music. The thing about the movie is that it was a mid-90s underground low-budget US movie, which wasn't released (to the theaters or as a video tape) abroad and of course didn't stand a chance when a few years later the DVD re-releases begun. So, unless you are a mid-40s hardcore-movie-fan who lived in a major US city 15 years ago, I think I just won the bet. The soundtrack also didn't have a CD/LP/Cassette release (not even in the US). However it's more "popular" than the movie itself, even though the performing group disbanded one year after the recording (before even the movie got released). But, there is a fat chance that you've listened to this particular OST without having the profile mentioned before. You just have to be a thief. For all us fans (or just nostalgic music lovers) of the Shoegaze scene, who already know that this inverted popularity gap, between the movie and it's soundtrack, is because of Neil Halstead writing and Slowdive performing the whole thing, we are also aware that we simply can't purchase anything related to the movie. For the rest of you, just skip to the last paragraph of the post. I've spent countless hours for the past years, searching for a DVD/VHS/Screening of the movie and found nothing at all. I haven't even managed to take a peak by watching the trailer or some pictures. The only thing I came across was an ultra low quality movie-poster. Of course "pirate" downloading is not an option, since it's an action forbidden by law, hence a crime. And considering the fact that the illegal nature of this action comes from not allowing the contributors the money they deserve: downloading=stealing. Same of course applies to the soundtrack. Probably it's even worse, because the OST was never released on any physical/digital format, the band was dropped by their recording label a couple of years later, and the band itself does not exist anymore. So, under any circumstances, the band does not deserve any more financial recognition than their original paycheck, the song writer does not deserve any more artistic mention than his name written on the ending titles of the -hard to find- film, and most important, the musicophile does not deserve listening to this particular piece of music. Someone thought different though. So, he obtained a bootleg (a.k.a. illegal audio recording) of the soundtrack, ripped it to digital format, and uploaded it to the world-wide web available for download. That particular moment, something changed. Theft became a tempting option. There is no need to mention that I "snatched" a copy of it. And my action had those effects to everyone mentioned before (with a self-centered point of view):
  • Movie Director/Cast/Crew: I wanted to see their movie. Now I lust for it.
  • Production Company: They chose not to release the movie (wich I would watch -and now that I've listened to it's soundtrack- at any cost). So, there is no profit loss here.
  • Slowdive: They gained aftermath popularity, because now more people will have a chance to listen to it and therefore like it. (see link at the end of the post)
  • Neil Halstead: People are able to discover a so far unknown aspect of him. The one of the Film Music Composer.
  • Creation Records: They chose not to take the risk to release the OST, hence there is no actual "profit loss" here either. As for dropping Slowdive from their artists catalogue, everyone (including the author of this article) who bothered looking for the movie soundtrack, probably hate their guts already, so there is no -extra- popularity loss.
  • You: Thank me later...
  • The mid-40s US guy: Who cares about him? (Even though he's probably happy that someone mentions him on a blog for a different reason than blaming him for his country wars/murders/exploits and stuff like that)
So, with no further ado, I can provide you with a way to "break the law" and download this highly illegal masterpiece, by a simple download link. Since this ways is the only way. This album did not get a proper mastering, thus the volume in some tracks is differs from the others (movie volumes). Download (sendspace): Slowdive - I Am The Elephant, U Are The Mouse Note: This post, does NOT represent any beliefs or opinions of the Tsarouchi Soundsystem collective. It's just the personal perspective of the author. Music Regards, __convoitise P.S. If anyone knows or finds a way to purchase the OST, he may inform me and I will remove the download link (after I place an order).  Also, -just in case- McGee reads this, I would like to state clearly that I have nothing against Creation Records' staff & artists, even though their boss is a conservative wanker who has the gift of absolutely no taste in music.

item.title: Music Through Moving Images
item.dc:creator: tsarouchi
item.content:encoded:
Electro History X: Music through moving images [When OST is the Movie]
  • 24hr Party People [Britain, 2002]
_ THE  Film about Music. Located in Manchester, from 1976 to 1992, pictures the cornerstone of today's music. Every single artist of our days is somehow influenced from either Anthony 'Tony' Wilson (main character of the movie), his affliate bands (Joy Division, Happy Mondays, A Certain Ratio...), or from his actions ('Factory' Records, 'Hacienda' NightClub, 'So It Goes' TV Show...). _ Starring Steve Coogan as Tony Wilson. Also includes footage from several actual concerts. _ OST features songs by storyline bands such as: Buzzcocks, The Clash, 808 State, New Order .... http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A1Qz2x94q6A God (talking to Tony Wilson): It's a pity you didn't sign the Smiths, but you were right about Mick Hucknell. His music's rubbish, and he's a ginger.
  • High Fidelity [United States, 2000]
_ Movie adaption of Nick Hornby's book with the same title. Located in 90's Chicago (originally 90's London), this film is about the thin & discrete line between pop music and everyday life. This is not a movie about rock stars and massive gigs, this is a movie about every musicophile who just didn't get over his teenage years. As for the common dilema 'The Movie or The Book?' the answer is 'Both'. _ Starring John Cusack as Rob. Also, Tim Robbins as Ian _ OST features songs by pop bands such as: Kinks, Velvet Underground, Stereolab .... http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Vk_0qpFO8Tw Rob: What came first, the music or the misery? People worry about kids playing with guns, or watching violent videos, that some sort of culture of violence will take them over. Nobody worries about kids listening to thousands, literally thousands of songs about heartbreak, rejection, pain, misery and loss. Did I listen to pop music because I was miserable? Or was I miserable because I listened to pop music?
  • Fantasia [United States, 1940/1999]
_ These are the only two films -featured in this list- which were made for turning music into images. Walt Disney's vision made the original 'Fantasia' a breathtaking combination of pictures (drawn by his artists) and music (conducted by Leopold Stokowski, performed by the Philadelphia Orchestra). However, no matter how groundbreaking a movie is, time can be a ruthless enemy. So, just when the movie was about to be considered outdated, his cultural heirs filmed 'Fantasia 2000', keeping the spirit alive. This time the music was performed by Chicago Symphony Orchestra, conducted by James Levine. _ Hosts: Deems Taylor, Steve Martin, Penn & Teller, Quincy Jones ... _ OST features pieces by: Pyotr Tchaikovsky, Sebastian Bach, Ludwig van Beethoven .... http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XChxLGnIwCU Narrator (introducing the Nutcracker Suite) : You know it's funny how wrong an artist can be about his own work. Now the one composition of Tchaikovsky's that he really detested was his Nutcracker Suite, which is probably the most popular thing he ever wrote.
  • 24hr Party People [Britain, 2002]
_ THE  Film about Music. Located in Manchester, from 1976 to 1992, pictures the cornerstone of today's music. Every single artist of our days is somehow influenced from either Anthony 'Tony' Wilson (main character of the movie), his affliate bands (Joy Division, Happy Mondays, A Certain Ratio...), or from his actions ('Factory' Records, 'Hacienda' NightClub, 'So It Goes' TV Show...). _ Starring Steve Coogan as Tony Wilson. Also includes footage from several actual concerts. _ OST features songs by storyline bands such as: Buzzcocks, The Clash, 808 State, New Order .... http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A1Qz2x94q6A Gene (talking to a priest): I hear an 'Ave Maria' and my mind takes off on a syncopated version of it.
  1. Human Traffic
  2. It's All Gone Pete Tong
  3. Pi
  4. ?Ghost Dog
  5. Fantasia
  6. The Boat That Rocked
  7. Rockers
  8. Amadeus
  9. Billy Elliot
  10. Walk the Line
  11. This is Spinal Tap
  12. --Coffee & Cigarettes?

item.title: Dance Anthemns of the 90s [part 1: the pops]
item.dc:creator: tsarouchi
item.content:encoded:
Electro History X: Pioneers of Greek Electronic Scene
  • Underworld - Born Slippy (NUXX) [1995-1996]
Originally realeased in January 1995 as a B-Side to "Born Slippy", received little attention.  "Born Slippy .NUXX" was re-released as a single in 1996 charting #2 in UK and becoming the manifest of modern dance music, up to this day. It was voted #1 dance tune in Mixmag’s 25th Anniversary Awards. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XiMrrleH_hI&NR trivia: Born Slippy was the name of a greyhound the band bet on and won, and the .NUXX version took it's name from a computer error that added that suffix to the name of their working file
  • Hybrid - Finished Symphony [1999]
Released as a single in 1999 and featured on their debut album entitled "Wide Angle", was a remake of "Symphony", an older -unreleased- track by Hybrid. It became quite popular, but it's artistic impact was bigger than it's commercial success. It was the first breakbeat song that combined elements of trance, progressive house and symphonic music. A maxi-single with remixes, entitled "Finished Symphony Remixed" was released in 2008" http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yoV9d9y-DdQ trivia: The orchestral parts were performed by The Russian Federal Orchestra.
  • Puretone - Addicted to Bass [1998]
When someone uses the words "Australia" and "D&B" most people think of Pendulum. And that's too bad... "Addicted to Bass" is the very first Drum and Bass tune that charted #2 in the UK. Written by the Australian band Puretone, it was meant to be the tune that made the term Drum and Bass slip into the mainstream. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wmwGGLrDvfE trivia: In Australia reached just #19 in the charts.
  • Chemical Brothers - Block Rockin' Beats [1997]
"Block Rockin' Beats" received a Grammy award for "Best Instrumental Rock Perfomance" and that's exactly why this song is on this list. Chemical Brothers considered to be the pioneers of the Big Beat genre for some reason... When Tom Rowlands and Ed Simons wrote this song we cannot know if they wanted to make an electronic rock tune or a rock-ish electro tune. Embracing both rock and electro fans, reached a wide audience and instantly became #1 in the UK. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fSp81g9kzu8 trivia: Chemical Brothers original called themselves Dust Brothers (after a hip hop duo with that name) and changed it when the original Dust Brothers threatened legal action over the use of their name.
  • FatBoy Slim - Right Here, Right Now [1999]
Take an artist with one of the best backgrounds in music industry. At the peak of his career, he made an album that was about to become his evangelion. Choose a catchy song from it. Add a cool video to this tune, and you've got "Right Here, Right Now". http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ub747pprmJ8 trivia: The lyrics "right here, right now" are a sample of Angela Bassett's voice from the film Strange Days
  • Future Sound Of London - Papua New Guinea [1991]
The debut single from the FSOL (and later appeared on the album "Accelerator") is probably the most remixed song of it's era, having various remixes released up to this day (my personal pick is Hybrids' version). The original version is a breakbeat track, featuring numerous samples from "Radio Babylon" of Meat Beat Manifesto and one of the most recognized piano melodies in electronic music. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OjQqYFNK50M trivia: Papua New Guinea 2001 is a remixes collection released in 2002 featuring versions by Satoshie Tomiie, Hybrid, Blue States and Simian Mobile Disco
  • Baby D - Let Me Be Your Fantasy [1992]
Featuring female vocals in a breakbeat track -even nowadays- is kinda risky. Perhaps that's the reason why Baby Ds' "Let Me Be Your Fantasy" first release in 1992, draw the attention of very few DJs. However, after it's re-issue in 1994, entered the charts in position #3 and peaked #1. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7Wt1nvsoKno trivia: Baby D released his version of Kongis' "Everybody's Got To Learn Sometime", entitled I Need Your Loving" (UK #3)
